revisions.rev:
{{Infobox Artist Discography | Artist = [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] video | Image = Stickyandsweet candy shop.jpg | Image size = 240px | Caption = Madonna performing on her 2008â09 [[Sticky & Sweet Tour]] | Alt = Madonna on stage, wearing a black coat over a black leotard and long black boots. She is flanked by two males in formal suits. The men are sitting on one leg and holds out their hats to Madonna who sings into a microphone in her left hand. The backdrop displays tiny sparkling red lights. | Music videos = 66 | MV link = Music videos | Option = 9 | Option name = Concert tour videos | Option link = Concert tour videos | Option color = gold | 1Option = 4 | 1Option name = Video compilations | 1Option link = Music video compilations | 1Option color = #87CEFA | 2Option = 4 | 2Option name = Video singles | 2Option link = Video singles | 2Option color = #C0C0C0 | 3Option = 2 | 3Option name = Documentaries | 3Option link = Documentaries | 3Option color = #9ACD32 | 4Option = 2 | 4Option name = Box sets | 4Option link = Box sets | 4Option color = #E97451 | 5Option = 4 | 5Option name = Promotional videos | 5Option link = Promotional videos | 5Option color = #F34899 | References = Yes | Ref link = Notes }} The [[videography]] of American singer-songwriter [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] consists of sixty-six [[music videos]], nine [[concert|concert tour videos]], four [[compilation album|music video compilations]], four [[VHS#VHS single|music video singles]], two [[documentary|documentaries]], two box sets and four promotional videos. In 1982 Madonna signed a recording contract with [[Sire Records]], a label owned by [[Warner Bros. Records]], and released her first two singles before launching her [[Madonna (album)|eponymous]] debut album.{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/bbcom/news/madonna-plans-new-tracks-for-hits-collection-1003952554.story |title=Madonna Plans New Tracks For Hits Collection|date=2009-03-18|accessdate=2009-08-21|last=Caulfield|first=Keith|work=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc}} Madonna's first music video was for the single "[[Everybody (Madonna song)|Everybody]]", for which Sire Records created a low budget, in-house video. Her first video to receive attention on [[MTV]] was "[[Borderline (song)|Borderline]]" which was followed by "[[Lucky Star (song)|Lucky Star]]".{{harvnb|Cross|2007|p=30}} In 1984 Madonna released "[[Like a Virgin (song)|Like a Virgin]]", the lead single from her second album of the [[Like a Virgin|same name]]. The video portrayed Madonna roaming through the streets of Venice and lying in a white wedding dress.{{harvnb|Cross|2007|p=32}} The same year she also released the follow-up single, "[[Material Girl]]".{{harvnb|Guilbert|2002|p=42}} Madonna's third studio album, ''[[True Blue (Madonna album)|True Blue]]'', was released in 1986. The video for the lead single, "[[Live to Tell]]", ushered in a new image for Madonna.{{harvnb|Metz|Benson|1999|p=50}} With the video of "[[True Blue (Madonna song)|True Blue]]", Madonna's impact on MTV and popular music was established when a contest entitled ''Making My Video'', was held to create a music video for the song.{{harvnb|Clerk|2002|p=99}} "[[La Isla Bonita]]" and "[[Who's That Girl (Madonna song)|Who's That Girl]]", both released in 1987, portrayed Madonna's fascination with Hispanic culture and the inclusion of religious symbolism.{{harvnb|Fouz-HernÃ¡ndez|Jarman-Ivens|2004|p=67}} In 1989 Madonna signed a $5 million deal with [[Pepsi]] to use her song "[[Like a Prayer (song)|Like a Prayer]]" in one of their commercial advertisements. Madonna also wanted to use the commercial for the global debut of the song and her [[Like a Prayer|similar titled]] studio album. However, when Madonna released the actual music video of the song it faced strong reaction from religious groups and media. The video portrayed Madonna dancing in front of burning crosses, receiving [[stigmata]], kissing a black saint and having sex with him in a church altar. Her other notable videos released that year included "[[Express Yourself (Madonna song)|Express Yourself]]" and "[[Cherish (Madonna song)|Cherish]]" which were critically appreciated for their positive feminist themes.{{harvnb|Taraborrelli|2002|p=56}} In 1990 Madonna released the song "[[Vogue (Madonna song)|Vogue]]", which portrayed the underground gay subculture dance routine called [[vogue (dance)|voguing]], as well as the glamorous look of Hollywood stars. The same year she released "[[Justify My Love]]", whose video featured Madonna in an erotic dream containing [[sadomasochism]], [[voyeurism]] and [[bisexuality]]. MTV deemed the video too explicit and banned it from airing on their channel. In 1992 Madonna released her fifth studio album, ''[[Erotica (Madonna album)|Erotica]]''. The [[Erotica (song)|similar titled]] lead single's video portrayed Madonna as a masked dominatrix. The video of "[[Deeper and Deeper]]" depicted Madonna as [[Andy Warhol]]'s protÃ©gÃ© [[Edie Sedgwick]]. In 1994 she released "[[Secret (Madonna song)|Secret]]", the lead single from her sixth studio album, ''[[Bedtime Stories (Madonna album)|Bedtime Stories]]''. The video showed scenes of [[reincarnation|rebirth]], [[transvestism|transvestites]] and [[damnation]], which are interspersed with Madonna walking down a street to her home.{{harvnb|Miklitsch|1998|p=124}} "[[Bedtime Story (Madonna song)|Bedtime Story]]", from the same album, showed a dream sequence, inspired by paintings of [[Frida Kahlo]] and [[Remedios Varo]], while incorporating [[new age]] surrealistic images.{{harvnb|Fouz-HernÃ¡ndez|Jarman-Ivens|2004|p=56}} In 1998, Madonna released her seventh studio album, ''[[Ray of Light]]''. The music video for the lead single, "[[Frozen (song)|Frozen]]", ushered in a new image for her with the incorporation of Indian influences.{{harvnb|Metz|Benson|1999|p=168}} The video for the [[Ray of Light (song)|title single]] was a [[Fast forward|high-speed]] one, portraying people going through their daily lives, with images of Madonna in black denim dancing to the music. Her fascination and incorporation of Asian culture continued with the video of "[[Nothing Really Matters]]" (1999) where she appeared as a [[geisha]]. In 2000 Madonna released her eighth studio album, ''[[Music (Madonna album)|Music]]''. The [[Music (Madonna song)|title single]] featured her in the role of a [[pimp]] while changing her image to that of a glamorous cowgirl.{{harvnb|Fouz-HernÃ¡ndez|Jarman-Ivens|2004|p=94}} The video for the last single, "[[What It Feels Like for a Girl]]", portrayed Madonna going around the city in a car, accompanied by an old woman, and vandalising as well as committing crimes. This fascination for violence continued with the music videos of "[[Die Another Day (song)|Die Another Day]]" (2002) and "[[American Life (song)|American Life]]" (2003), the lead single from her ninth studio album [[American Life|of the same name]].{{cite news|url=http://www.welt.de/vermischtes/article836335/Die_teuersten_Musikvideos_aller_Zeiten.html|title=Die teuersten Musikvideos aller Zeiten|date=2007-04-27|work=[[Die Welt]]|publisher=[[Axel Springer AG]]|accessdate=2009-12-24|language=German}} The video for the latter, shot [[2003 invasion of Iraq|pre-Iraq war of 2003]], portrayed a military-chic fashion show.{{harvnb|Fouz-HernÃ¡ndez|Jarman-Ivens|2004|p=123}} Madonna's tenth studio album, ''[[Confessions on a Dance Floor]]'', was released in 2005. The video for the lead single, "[[Hung Up]]", was a tribute to [[John Travolta]] and his movies. Her eleventh studio album, ''[[Hard Candy (Madonna album)|Hard Candy]]'', was released in 2008; its lead single, "[[4 Minutes (Madonna song)|4 Minutes]]", portrayed her as a superhero, tackling physical obstacles. Her most recent music video for the song "[[Celebration (Madonna song)|Celebration]]" was critiqued as a return to her dance roots. Madonna has worked with many successful directors and produced music videos that are considered by some as works of art. Her videos have depicted controversial subjects such as teen pregnancy, racism, religion, sex, and violence. In their book, ''The Madonna Companion: Two Decades of Commentary'', authors Allen Metz and Carol Benson stated that more than any other recent pop star, Madonna has used MTV and music videos to establish her popularity and to enhance her recorded work. According to them:
"It's hard to imagine discussing many of her songs without discussing any of the related videos. Most of the controversy surrounding her most-discussed songs, notably "Like a Prayer", has to do with the video images created to promote the song, rather than the song itself. In fact, many of her seem more significant than they are because of the impact of the accompanying videos."{{harvnb|Metz|Benson|1999|p=161}}
Madonna has been honored with 20 [[MTV Video Music Award]]sâthe most for any artistâincluding the lifetime achievement "[[MTV Video Vanguard Award|Video Vanguard Award]]" in 1986.{{cite journal|title=Who has won the most MTV Video Music Awards?|date=March 2008|work=[[Vibe (magazine)|Vibe]]|publisher=Vibe Media Group|issn=1070-4701|volume=16|issue=2|page=58|ref=harv}} In 2003, MTV named her "The Greatest Music Video Star Ever" and said that "Madonna's innovation, creativity and contribution to the music video art form is what won her the award."{{harvnb|Landrum|2007|p=258}} ==Music videos== ===1980s=== {| class="wikitable" width=98% |- ! width=3%|Year ! width=15%| Music video ! width=15%| Director(s) ! width=65%| Notes |- |1982 |"[[Everybody (Madonna song)|Everybody]]" |[[Ed Steinberg]]{{harvnb|Morton|2002|p=332}} |An in-house video featuring Madonna singing with a group of dancers against a neon-lit background{{harvnb|Cross|2007|p=26}} |- |rowspan="2"|1983 |"[[Burning Up]]" |[[Steve Barron]] |The video portrays Madonna, in a white dress, writhing on a road, singing the song about her lover. The boy drives a car, presumably to run her over.{{harvnb|Allen|1987|p=281}} |- |"[[Holiday (Madonna song)|Holiday]]" |Unknown |The original music video was never released. |- |rowspan="3"|1984 |"[[Borderline (song)|Borderline]]" |[[Mary Lambert]] |The video portrays Madonna as a Hispanic girl dancing on the streets. She leaves her boyfriend to be with a photographer but ultimately rejects him and comes back to her boyfriend.{{harvnb|Kellner|1995|p=327}} |- |"[[Lucky Star (song)|Lucky Star]]" |Arthur Pierson |The video portrays Madonna in her boy-toy image, dancing in front of a white background, flanked by two dancers.{{harvnb|Metz|Benson|1999|p=162}} |- |"[[Like a Virgin (song)|Like a Virgin]]" |rowspan="2"|Mary Lambert |In the video, Madonna roamed around the streets of Venice and through marble-pillared rooms wearing a white wedding dress; this clip was interspersed by images of a lion and a man wearing a lion mask. It faced negative reaction from family organizations and social workers, who complained that it promoted sex outside marriage and undermined family values, offering an unsavory image of Madonna as a whore.{{harvnb|Whiteley|2000|p=136}} |- |rowspan="5"|1985 |"[[Material Girl]]" |Pictured as a video-within-a-video, Madonna sang the song dressed up in a pink sleeveless gown, flanked by boys in black coats. The video imitated [[Marilyn Monroe]]'s version of "[[Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend#Marilyn Monroe version|Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend]]" from the 1953 film ''[[Gentlemen Prefer Blondes (film)|Gentlemen Prefer Blondes]]''. The video and the song together culminated in Madonna's nickname as "material girl" in mainstream media.{{harvnb|Metz|Benson|1999|p=277}} |- |"[[Crazy for You (song)|Crazy for You]]" |Harold Becker |Made with clips from the movie ''[[Vision Quest]]''{{harvnb|Metz|Benson|1999|p=310}} |- |"[[Into the Groove]]" |Susan Seidelman |Made with film clips from ''[[Desperately Seeking Susan]]''. |- |"[[Gambler (Madonna song)|Gambler]]" |Harold Becker |Made with clips from the movie ''[[Vision Quest]]'' |- |"[[Dress You Up]]" |Danny Kleinman |The video was released with footage from [[The Virgin Tour]]. |- |rowspan="4"|1986 |"[[Live to Tell]]" |rowspan="3"|[[James Foley]]{{harvnb|Metz|Benson|1999|p=309}} |The video portrays Madonna with a new pale and subtle look, her shoulder-length hair was wavy and [[golden blond]]. She got rid of her junk jewellery and adopted a pale make-up look with shoulder-length golden locks. The look was again inspired by Monroe.{{harvnb|Voller|1999|p=24}} Footage from the movie ''[[At Close Range]]'' were interspersed, with Madonna appearing to speak for the character.{{harvnb|Butler|2002|p=232}} |- |"[[Papa Don't Preach]]" |In this video, Madonna adopted the [[gamine]] look portrayed by [[Shirley MacLaine]] and [[Audrey Hepburn]] during the 1950s.{{harvnb|Voller|1999|p=25}} She portrays a [[tomboy]] who wants to tell her father about her pregnancy. Interspersed with scenes of a sexier Madonna with a toned body, wearing a black bustier.{{harvnb|Mansour|2005|p=352}} |- |"[[True Blue (Madonna song)|True Blue]]" |The American version from [[MTV]]'s Make My Video Contest was directed by Ãngel Gracia and Cliff Guest, where Madonna does not appear. The international release directed by Foley portrays Madonna and her friends in an all-blue [[diner]].{{harvnb|Clerk|2002|p=49}} |- |"[[Open Your Heart (Madonna song)|Open Your Heart]]" |[[Jean-Baptiste Mondino]] |The video paid homage to actresses [[Liza Minnelli]] and [[Marlene Dietrich]]. Madonna played an exotic dancer in a peep-show club who befriends a little boy and escapes from there. The video was negatively criticised, because it portrays the entry of a child in a strip club.{{harvnb|Bordo|Heywood|2004|p=273}}{{harvnb|Dirks|Eley|Ortner|1994|p=471}} |- |rowspan="4"|1987 |"[[La Isla Bonita]]" |Mary Lambert |Madonna played a woman living in a Spanish ''[[barrio]]''. She portrays two characters: a boyishly-dressed Catholic woman and a colorful Flamenco dancer. The video portrays Madonna's fascination with Hispanic culture and the inclusion of religious symbolism.{{harvnb|Rettenmund|1995|p=98}} |- |"[[Who's That Girl (Madonna song)|Who's That Girl]]" |Peter Rosenthal{{harvnb|Metz|Benson|1999|p=314}} |The video portrays Madonna dressed in Spanish style as a young lady in search of a treasure. It included scenes from [[Who's That Girl (1987 film)|the film of the same name]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1987/08/23/movies/film-view-in-search-of-madonna-s-persona.html|title=Film View; In Search of Madonna's Persona|last=Canby|first=Vincent|date= 1987-08-23|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2009-07-09}} |- |"[[Causing a Commotion]]" |Unknown |A live performance from the [[Who's That Girl World Tour]] in [[Turin, Italy]]. Another version included the performance at the [[1987 MTV Video Music Awards]]. |- |"[[The Look of Love (Madonna song)|The Look of Love]]" |James Foley |Compilation video of clips from ''[[Who's That Girl (1987 film)|Who's That Girl]]'' |- |rowspan="5"|1989 |"[[Like a Prayer (song)|Like a Prayer]]" |Mary Lambert |The video portrays Madonna to be a witness of an interracial murder and goes to pray in a church. Various scenes like Madonna kissing a black saint, receiving [[stigmata]], scantily dressed and dancing in front of burning crosses are shown. In the end, she helps to free the man who was falsely accused of murder.{{harvnb|Taraborrelli|2002|p=167}} Religious groups protested that the video was a blasphemous use of Christian imagery. The Pope banned Madonna from appearing in Italy and urged a national boycott of Pepsi. The latter withdrew their contract with Madonna while letting her keep the $5 million.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/7922129.stm|title=Madonna's banned advert |last=Hand|first=John|date=2009-03-05|work=''[[BBC]]''|publisher=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=2009-12-16}} |- |"[[Express Yourself (Madonna song)|Express Yourself]]" |[[David Fincher]] |Inspired by the film ''[[Metropolis (film)|Metropolis]]'', the video portrays Madonna as the leader of a company, and later as a glamorous lady and chained masochist. Muscular men act as her workers. In the end, Madonna picked one of them to be her [[dating (activity)|date]].{{harvnb|Guilbert|2002|p=120}} The music video for "Express Yourself" was the most expensive video at the time of its release with production cost of $5 million.{{cite news|url=http://top40.about.com/od/madonna/tp/madonnatop10.01.htm|title=Madonna's 37 Top 10 Pop Songs|last=Lamb|first=Bill|date=2008-05-01|work=''[[About.com]]''|accessdate=2009-12-24}} |- |"[[Cherish (Madonna song)|Cherish]]" |[[Herb Ritts]] |Madonna played on the beach with [[Merman|mermen]] and merchild. In the end she falls in love with one of the mermen.{{harvnb|Guilbert|2002|p=45}} |- |"[[Dear Jessie]]" |Derek Hayes |An animated video featuring Madonna as an animated fairy. The video was released only outside the United States.{{harvnb|Bego|2000|p=78}} |- |"[[Oh Father]]" |David Fincher |A black-and-white video portraying the death scene of a young mother and the tempestuous relationship that ensues between the husband and the daughter. Years later Madonna, as the grown-up daughter, reconciles with the father at the woman's grave.{{harvnb|Clerk|2002|p=80}} |- |} ===1990s=== {| class="wikitable" width=98% |- ! width=3%|Year ! width=15%| Music video ! width=15%| Director(s) ! width=65%| Notes |- |rowspan="2"|1990 |"[[Vogue (Madonna song)|Vogue]]" |David Fincher |Black-and-white video recreating the glamorous look of old [[Hollywood]] with men in suits and Madonna dressed in gowns.{{harvnb|Metz|Benson|1999|p=282}} It also displayed the dance form called [[Vogue (dance)|vogue]].{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,317277,00.html|title=What, me vogue?|last=Cagle|first=Jess|date=1990-05-04|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|accessdate=2009-12-08}} The video was praised for making the sex and gender roles ambiguous in its portrayal of people, and for bringing an underground culture in the mainstream limelight.{{harvnb|Metz|Benson|1999|p=283}} |- |"[[Justify My Love]]" |Jean-Baptiste Mondino |Black-and-white video portraying Madonna coming to a hotel room to satisfy her sexual fantasy. Scenes of [[sadomasochism]], [[voyeurism]] and [[bisexuality]] are also portrayed.{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,285759,00.html|title=Madonna Banned|last=Rich|first=Joshua|date=1998-11-20|work=Entertainment Weekly|publisher=Time Inc|accessdate=2009-12-08}} Critics were polarized over the video's content with some of them applauding Madonna's boldness while others took the brazenness of the video negatively. Madonna called the video "a celebration of sex". She released the video as a video single and it went on to become the best-selling music video single of all time, earning a four-times [[RIAA certification|platinum]] certification from the [[Recording Industry Association of America]]. |- |rowspan="3"|1992 |"[[This Used to Be My Playground]]" |[[Alek Keshishian]] |The video is a walkthrough of memories. While Madonna melancholically sings about the old days, the viewer flips through a photo album which feature moving images of a singing Madonna as well as images from the movie ''[[A League of Their Own]]''.{{cite journal|last=Pitman|first=Randy|date=2000-08-27|title=The Video Librarian|publisher=[[University of Michigan]]|volume=19|issn=0887-6851|oclc=13306621|accessdate=2009-12-08}} |- |"[[Erotica (song)|Erotica]]" |[[Fabien Baron]] |Madonna is portrayed as a masked dominatrix with a golden tooth and a whip. Montages of sexual imagery are shown that were shot during the photography of Madonna's ''[[Sex (book)|Sex]]'' book. It was a montage of sexually charged images, designed to shock the audience. MTV put the video into [[Rotation (music)|heavy rotaion]], but only after midnight.{{harvnb|Taraborrelli|2002|p=227}} |- |"[[Deeper and Deeper]]" |Bobby Woods |Madonna portrays [[Andy Warhol|Warhol]] [[Mentorship|protÃ©gÃ©]] [[Edie Sedgwick]]. She goes to a disco and looks for something which ends with a man releasing the balloons she was carrying. Interspersed with scenes of Madonna being photographed and she and her friends watching a man dancing in underwear.{{harvnb|Guilbert|2002|p=69}} |- |rowspan="4"|1993 |"[[Bad Girl (Madonna song)|Bad Girl]]" |David Fincher |The video opens and closes with shots of a murdered Madonna, who, having lived a life of promiscuous sex, presumably joins her dead lover and guardian angel, portrayed by actor [[Christopher Walken]].{{harvnb|Fouz-HernÃ¡ndez|Jarman-Ivens|2004|p=181}} |- |"[[Fever (Madonna song)|Fever]]" |[[StÃ©phane Sednaoui]] |The video portrays Madonna as a [[Balinese art|Balinese idol]] with red hair and another shot of her being silver painted. Interspersed with scenes of a man in thongs, his body painted gold.{{harvnb|Fouz-HernÃ¡ndez|Jarman-Ivens|2004|p=91}} |- |"[[Rain (Madonna song)|Rain]]" |[[Mark Romanek]] |The video portrays Madonna with short cropped, black hair, recording the song in a studio. Interspersed with scenes of Madonna kissing a man behind a glass on which water falls.{{harvnb|Meyers|1999|p=326}} Critical appreciation came for the music video, whose technical brilliance was awarded at the [[1993 MTV Video Music Awards]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/ontv/vma/winners-by-category.jhtml|title=MTV Video Music Awards > Winners By Category |work=''[[MTV]]''|publisher=[[MTV Networks]]|accessdate=2009-12-15}} |- |"[[Bye Bye Baby (Madonna song)|Bye Bye Baby]]" |Unknown |Live performances from [[The Girlie Show World Tour|The Girlie Show Tour]] and the [[1993 MTV Video Music Awards]].{{harvnb|Beemyn|Eliason|1996|p=318}} |- |rowspan="3"|1994 |"[[I'll Remember]]" |Alek Keshishian{{harvnb|Cross|2007|p=290}} |Madonna singing the song in a recording studio, while being supervised by herself in an androgynous look. Interspersed with clips from the movie ''[[With Honors (film)|With Honors]]''.{{harvnb|Clerk|2002|p=112}} |- |"[[Secret (Madonna song)|Secret]]" |Melodie McDaniel |Black-and-white video featuring Madonna as a blues singer singing in a club. Scenes of [[reincarnation|rebirth]], [[transvestism|transvestites]] and [[damnation]] are interspersed with Madonna walking down a street to her home. |- |"[[Take a Bow (Madonna song)|Take a Bow]]" |[[Michael Haussman]] |Madonna portrays the mistress of a Spanish bullfighter. Their affair ends after Madonna is being abused by the fighter. Religious imagery forms the backbone of the video.{{harvnb|Fouz-HernÃ¡ndez|Jarman-Ivens|2004|p=147}} |- |rowspan="4"|1995 |"[[Bedtime Story (Madonna song)|Bedtime Story]]" |Mark Romanek |A surreal dream sequence arising from some sort of controlled experiment on a prostrate Madonna, lying in a blue spaceship-like room.{{harvnb|Clerk|2002|p=132}} The production cost of the video was $5 million, making it one of the costliest videos.{{cite news|url=http://www.ropeofsilicon.com/article/comparing_tarsems_fall_and_cell_to_romaneks_bedtime_story|title=Comparing Tarsem's 'Fall' and 'Cell' to Romanek's 'Bedtime Story' |last=Brevett|first=Brad|date=2008-06-11|publisher=Rope of Silicon.com|accessdate=2009-12-24}} The video was honored as a permanent collection in New York's [[Museum of Modern Art]] in 1996.{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/new/home.nsf/webpages/onehourphotox09x09x02|title= One Hour Photo â Robin Williams Gets Obsessive|last=Press|first=Contact Music|date=2002-09-09|publisher=[[Contactmusic.com]]|accessdate=2009-12-17}} |- |"[[Human Nature (Madonna song)|Human Nature]]" |Jean-Baptiste Mondino |Madonna and her dancers in front of a white background, wearing black, PVC catsuits, perform a number of [[Sadomasochism|S&M]]-inspired dance moves. |- |"[[I Want You (Madonna song)|I Want You]]" |Earle Sebastian |The single release was cancelled but the music video was still released. The black-and-white video portrays Madonna waiting for her lover's telephone call.{{harvnb|Taraborrelli|2004|p=242}} |- |"[[You'll See]]" |Michael Haussman |Sequel to the music video of "Take a Bow". Madonna leaves the bullfighter but he still chases her around the world. Ultimately she sets herself free from him. |- |rowspan="3"|1996 |"[[Love Don't Live Here Anymore (Madonna song)|Love Don't Live Here Anymore]]" |Jean-Baptiste Mondino |[[One shot (music video)|Single-shot]] [[Photographic print toning#Sepia toning|sepia]]-colored video showing Madonna in the middle of an empty [[Suite (hotel)|suite]] of an abandoned hotel.{{harvnb|Vernallis|2004|p=166}} |- |"[[You Must Love Me]]" |rowspan="3"|[[Alan Parker]] |Madonna was pregnant with her daughter Lourdes at the time of shooting the video. Her stomach was hidden behind a piano in the video. |- |"[[Don't Cry for Me Argentina (Madonna song)|Don't Cry for Me Argentina]]" |rowspan="2"|The music videos for "Don't Cry for Me Argentina" and "Another Suitcase in Another Hall" are excerpts from the film ''[[Evita (film)|Evita]]''. |- |1997 |"[[Another Suitcase in Another Hall]]" |- |rowspan="4"|1998 |"[[Frozen (song)|Frozen]]" |[[Chris Cunningham]] |An all-blue video shot in the middle of [[Mojave Desert]]. Dressed in black clothing from head to foot, her long hair colored black and straight and [[mehndi]] on her hands, Madonna portrays a mystical creature and a witchy persona who sometimes turns into a dog, sometimes into a bird and sometimes [[Levitation|levitates]] from the ground.{{harvnb|Guilbert|2002|p=172}} |- |"[[Ray of Light (song)|Ray of Light]]" |[[Jonas Ãkerlund]] |A high-speed video, showing ordinary people doing their daily routines. In between Madonna, dressed in casual jeans and flowing golden hair, dances to the song, ultimately falling asleep on a dance floor. It won the [[MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year|Video of the Year]] award at the [[1998 MTV Video Music Awards]].{{cite news|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-56351997.html|title=Madonna's 'Ray of Light' shines at MTV awards|last=Cardwell|first=Annette|date=1998-09-12|work=[[Boston Herald]]|publisher=Herald Media Inc|accessdate=2009-12-09}} |- |"[[Drowned World/Substitute for Love]]" |[[Walter Stern (director)|Walter Stern]] |Portrays Madonna running away from the paparazzi in a car. After reaching home she takes her daughter in her arms. |- |"[[The Power of Good-Bye]]" |[[Matthew Rolston]] |Madonna and her lover play chess, and Madonna wins. After her lover reprimands her, Madonna goes out to the beach and starts walking along the shore, where she possibly commits suicide.{{cite news|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1P2-17697912.html|title=Madonna TV|last=Solomon|first=Rizal|date=2000-11-03|work=[[The Malay Mail]]|publisher=[[Media Prima Berhad]]|accessdate=2009-12-09}} |- |rowspan="2"|1999 |"[[Nothing Really Matters]]" |Johan Renck |Japanese-themed video, featuring Madonna as a [[geisha]] wearing a red kimono and white clad Swedes of Asian heritage performing [[butoh]] dance moves.{{cite news|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-53853157.html|title=Madonna's "Nothing Really Matters" World Premieres On MTV|last=Reporter|first=BW|date=1999-02-11|work=[[Business Wire]]|publisher=[[Berkshire Hathaway]]|accessdate=2009-12-09}} |- |"[[Beautiful Stranger]]" |[[Brett Ratner]] |Shot for the movie ''[[Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me]]'' (1999), the video features Madonna dancing in a club and actor [[Mike Myers (actor)|Mike Myers]] as Austin Power trying to seduce her; his plan ultimately backfiring.{{cite news|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-60421547.html|title=Madonna's to spy for Austin Power|last=Strong|first=Brenda|date=1999-05-21|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|accessdate=2009-12-09}} |- |} ===2000s=== {| class="wikitable" width=98% |- ! width=3%|Year ! width=15%| Music video ! width=15%| Director(s) ! width=65%| Notes |- |rowspan="3"|2000 |"[[American Pie (song)#Madonna cover|American Pie]]" |Philip Stolzl |Madonna sings the song in front of a giant [[Flag of the United States]]. Interspersed with scenes which are characteristic of the American life. Actor [[Rupert Everett]] makes an appearance.{{cite news|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-60286077.html|title=Madonna's bum wiped; She Censors Video|last=Wright|first=Matthew|date=2000-02-12|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=Trinity Mirror|accessdate=2009-12-09}} |- |"[[Music (Madonna song)|Music]]" |Jonas Ãkerlund |Madonna and her friends board a limousine which takes them to a strip-club and disco. The strippers are brought over in the limousine by Madonna and her friends. An animated section is present where Madonna fights with some goons.{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/music/videos/m/madonna-music.shtml|title=Madonna: Music < PopMatters|last=Nettles|first=John G.|date=2004-09-12|publisher=[[PopMatters]]|accessdate=2009-12-09}} |- |"[[Don't Tell Me (Madonna song)|Don't Tell Me]]" |Jean-Baptiste Mondino |The video shows Madonna walking on a [[conveyor belt]] in front of a video screen where cowboys are shown dancing. They join Madonna in front of the screen near the end of the video.{{cite news|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-69200459.html|title=Warner Bros. Records Selects CDKnet.|last=Reporter|first=BW|date=2001-01-16|work=Business Wire|publisher=Berkshire Hathaway|accessdate=2009-12-09}} |- |2001 |"[[What It Feels Like for a Girl]]" |[[Guy Ritchie]] |Madonna picks up an old woman from an old-age home and speeds down the streets with her in a car. While driving she commits a number of crimes, including theft, destruction of property and murder. The video was banned in the United States for being too violent. The audio used in the video is the [[Above & Beyond]] remix instead of the original album version.{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,103315,00.html|title="What It Feels Like for a Girl" â DVD |last=Fonseca|first=Nicholas|date=2001-03-22|work=Entertainment Weekly|publisher=Time Inc|accessdate=2009-12-09}} |- |2002 |"[[Die Another Day (song)|Die Another Day]]" |[[Traktor]] |Features a heavily-beat-up Madonna being brought to be executed in a [[gas chamber]]. Interspersed with scenes of a white-dressed and black-dressed Madonna sword fighting. In the end Madonna escapes from the execution.{{cite news|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1P1-68607675.html|title=Madonna Tries Out Karate in Video|last=Partridge|first=James|date=2002-10-02|work=[[Daily Mail]]|publisher=[[Associated Newspapers]]|accessdate=2009-12-09}} The former's video was the second most expensive video, production cost being around $6 million. |- |rowspan="4"|2003 |"[[American Life (song)|American Life]]" |Jonas Ãkerlund |Original video showed Madonna among military-garbed models at a fashion show. Interspersed with shots of the catwalk was footage of explosions and planes dropping bombs. The video ends with Madonna throwing what appears to be a grenade into the lap of a [[George W. Bush]] lookalike.{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,439329,00.html|title=Miss 'American'|last=Susman|first=Gary|date=2003-04-01|work=Entertainment Weekly|publisher=Time Inc|accessdate=2009-12-10}} Western models, wearing military garments are followed on the catwalk by [[Middle Eastern]] child victims of war. Madonna had initially claimed that the video was non-specific and anti-war. However, before its premiere on music channels in March 2003, Madonna cancelled the release and issued a statement saying that, "I do not believe that it is appropriate to air it [the video] at this time. Due to the volatile state of the world and out of sensitivity and respect for the armed forces, who I support and pray for, I do not want to risk offending anyone who might misinterpret the meaning of this video." Because of this, Madonna filmed the second version of the video that featured her singing in front of the world's flags. |- |"[[Hollywood (Madonna song)|Hollywood]]" |Jean-Baptiste Mondino |Madonna portrays some of [[Hollywood]]'s former actresses and the upheaval of a glamorous life.{{cite news|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G1-103492680.html|title=Madonna in the image of Hollywood stars for her latest pop video|last=Benjamin|first=Laura|date=2003-06-17|work=Daily Mail|publisher=Associated Newspapers|accessdate=2009-12-10}} |- |"[[Me Against the Music]]" ([[Britney Spears]] featuring Madonna) |Paul Hunter |Britney Spears and Madonna are shown in a club, playing opposite characters with Britney in the dark and Madonna in the white. A cat-and-mouse like chase ensues; Spears catches up to Madonna in the end.{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1626705/20091119/spears_britney.jhtml|title=Britney Spears And Madonna 'Tease' Fans In 'Me Against The Music' Video|last=Vena|first=Jocelyn|coauthors=Elias, Matt|date=2009-11-20|work=MTV|publisher=MTV Networks|accessdate=2009-12-10}} |- |"[[Love Profusion]]" |[[Luc Besson]] |Madonna walks on the sky and on the water with fairies, fishes, flowers and clouds surrounding her.{{cite news|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1P2-9172127.html|title=Madonna babbles her way into irrelevance|last=Jarvis|first=Judy|date=2003-05-01|work=[[Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.|Lancaster New Era]]|publisher=[[Lancaster Newspapers, Inc.]]|accessdate=2009-12-10}} |- |2005 |"[[Hung Up]]" |[[Johan Renck]] |The video portrays Madonna clad in a pink leotard dancing alone in a ballet studio and concludes at a gaming parlour where she dances with her backup troupe. Interspersed are scenes of people displaying their dancing skills in a variety of settings.{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1539338/20060824/madonna.jhtml|title=With No Director And Broken Ribs, Madonna Was 'Hung Up'|last=Vineyard|first=Jennifer|date=2006-08-25|work=MTV|publisher=MTV Networks|accessdate=2009-12-10}} |- |rowspan="3"|2006 |"[[Sorry (Madonna song)|Sorry]]" |[[Jamie King]] |A continuation from the "Hung Up" music video. Madonna and her troupe go around the town in a white van and dance in a skating arena.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-376758/That-looks-painful--bad-47-Madonna.html|title=That looks painful... not bad for 47, Madonna!|last=Moody|first=Clemmie|date=2006-02-10|work=Daily Mail|publisher=Associated Newspapers|accessdate=2009-12-10}} |- |"[[Get Together (Madonna song)|Get Together]]" |Logan |The video shows Madonna singing the song among graphical visuals portraying volcanoes erupting and a cityscape.{{cite web|url=http://new.music.yahoo.com/videos/madonna/get-together--33380280|title=Madonna â Get Together music video|publisher=[[Yahoo!]]|accessdate=2009-12-10}} |- |"[[Jump (Madonna song)|Jump]]" |Jonas Ãkerlund |The video features Madonna in a blond bob wig and singing the song in front of several neon signs. The video also features dancers performing the physical discipline [[parkour]].{{cite news|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2006/10/09/snap_judgment_m-2/|title=Snap Judgement: Madonna's 'Jump'|last=Slezak|first=Michael|date=2006-10-09|work=Entertainment Weekly|publisher=Time Inc|accessdate=2009-12-10}} |- |rowspan="3"|2008 |"[[4 Minutes (Madonna song)|4 Minutes]]" (featuring [[Justin Timberlake]] and [[Timbaland]]) |Jonas & FranÃ§ois |Madonna and Timberlake sing and run away from a giant black screen that devours everything in its path. At the end of the video, Madonna and Timberlake are consumed by the screen.{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1584741/20080403/madonna.jhtml|title=Madonna's '4 Minutes' Video Gets Online Sneak Peek|last=Harris|first=Chris|date=2008-04-03|work=MTV|publisher=MTv Networks|accessdate=2009-12-10}} |- |"[[Give It 2 Me]]" |Tom Munro,
Nathan Rissman |Madonna in retro-makeup look dancing in a photography studio in various garments. Cameo appearance by [[Pharrell Williams]].{{cite news|url=http://buzzworthy.mtv.com/2008/06/11/new-video-madonna-give-it-2-me/|title=New Video: Madonna, 'Give It 2 Me' |last=Cultured|first=Pop|date=2008-06-11|work=MTV|publisher=MTV Networks|accessdate=2009-12-10}} |- |"[[Miles Away (Madonna song)|Miles Away]]" |Nathan Rissman |Live footage from the [[Sticky & Sweet Tour]] in [[Buenos Aires]], mostly footage of the fans and stadium before and during the show. Originally unreleased, but finally included on the ''[[Celebration: The Video Collection]]'' DVD.{{cite news|url=http://www.madonna.com/news/title/celebration--track-listing-for-cd--dvd-announced|title=Madonna.com > News > 'Celebration' â Track Listing for CD & DVD Announced |last=Reporter|first=Icon|date=2009-08-25|work=''Icon: Official Madonna website''|publisher=Madonna.com|accessdate=2010-02-14}} |- |2009 |"[[Celebration (Madonna song)|Celebration]]" |Jonas Akerlund |A simple dance video featuring Madonna and her dancers doing the [[popping]] and [[locking (dance)|locking]] style of dancing against black-and-white backgrounds. The audio used in the video is the [[Benny Benassi]] remix instead of the original album version.{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1620512/20090901/madonna.jhtml|title=Madonna Returns To Her Dark Era With 'Celebration' Video|last=Montogomery|first=James|date=2009-09-01|work=MTV|publisher=MTV Networks|accessdate=2009-12-10}} |- |} ==Video albums== ===Concert tour videos=== {| class="wikitable" !align="center"| Year !align="center" width="350"| Video details ! Notes |- |1985 |''[[Live â The Virgin Tour|Live – The Virgin Tour]]'' *Released: November 1985 *Studio: [[Semtex_Films#Other_production_companies|Boy Toy, Inc.]] *Label: [[Sire Records|Sire]], [[Warner Music Vision|Warner Music Video]] *Format: VHS, Laserdisc | *Contains [[The Virgin Tour]] as shot live in Detroit, Michigan, 1985 in support of her second studio album ''Like a Virgin''.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/work/madonna-the-virgin-tour-live-64391|title=Madonna: The Virgin Tour (Live) > Overview|last=Deming|first=Mark|date=2006-09-12|work=''[[Allmovie]]''|publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=2009-12-10}} Was certified two-times multi-platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] for shipment of 200,000 units in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?resultpage=3&table=SEARCH_RESULTS&action=&title=&artist=madonna&format=ALBUM&debutLP=&category=&sex=&releaseDate=&requestNo=&type=&level=&label=&company=&certificationDate=&awardDescription=&catalogNo=&aSex=&rec_id=&charField=&gold=&platinum=&multiPlat=&level2=&certDate=&album=&id=&after=&before=&startMonth=1&endMonth=1&startYear=1958&endYear=2008&sort=Artist&perPage=25|title=Gold & Platinum database â Madonna|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]|accessdate=2009-12-10}} |- |1987 |''Who's That Girl â Live in Japan'' *Released: June 1987 *Studio: Boy Toy, Inc. *Label: Sire, [[Warner Music Vision|Warner Reprise Video]], [[Pioneer|Warner-Pioneer]] *Format: VHS, Laserdisc | *Contains the [[Who's That Girl World Tour]] live from Tokyo, Japan, 1987. It was a Japan-only release and was used as a cross-promotion for [[Mitsubishi]] Electronics, as Madonna had starred in television commercials in that country.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/work/madonna-whos-that-girl-live-30734|title=Madonna: Who's That Girl? (Live) > Overview |work=Allmovie|last=Fleming|first=Michael|date=2004-09-03|publisher=Rovi Corporation|accessdate=2009-12-10}} |- |1988 |''[[Ciao, Italia! â Live from Italy]]'' *Released: June 1988 *Studio: Boy Toy, Inc. *Label: Sire, Warner Reprise Video *Format: VHS, Laserdisc, DVD, VCD | *Contains the Who's That Girl World Tour live from Turin, Italy, 1987.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/work/madonna-ciao-italia-live-from-italy-64389|last=Deming|first=Mark|work=Allmovie|title=Madonna: Ciao Italia â Live from Italy > Overview|publisher=Rovi Corporation|accessdate=2009-12-11}} Was certified two-times platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] for shipment of 200,000 units in the United States. |- |rowspan="2"|1990 |''Blond Ambition â Japan Tour 90'' *Released: July 1990 *Studio: Music Guide, Inc. *Label: Sire, Warner-Pioneer *Format: VHS, Laserdisc | *Contains the [[Blond Ambition World Tour]], shot live from Yokohama, Japan, 1990. Was a Japan-only release.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/work/madonna-blonde-ambition-30737|last=Deming|first=Mark|work=Allmovie|title=Madonna: Blond Ambition â Japan Tour 90 > Overview|publisher=Rovi Corporation|accessdate=2009-12-11}} |- |''[[Live! â Blond Ambition World Tour 90]]'' *Released: December 1990 *Studio: Boy Toy, Inc. *Label: Pioneer Artists *Format: Laserdisc | *Contains the Blond Ambition World Tour as shot in Nice, France 1990. A Laserdisc-only release.{{harvnb|Guilbert|2002|p=254}} |- |1994 |''[[The Girlie Show â Live Down Under]]'' *Released: April 1994 *Studio: Music Tours, Inc. *Label: [[Maverick Records|Maverick]], Sire, Warner Reprise Video, [[Warner Music Vision]] *Format: VHS, DVD, Laserdisc, VCD | *Contains [[The Girlie Show World Tour]] shot live from Sydney, Australia, November 1993.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/work/madonna-the-girlie-show-live-down-under-158977|title=Madonna: The Girlie Show â Live Down Under > Overview |last=Pavlides|first=Dan|date=2006-03-23|work=Allmovie|publisher=Rovi Corporation|accessdate=2009-12-11}} Was certified gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] for shipment of 50,000 units in the United States. |- |2001 |''[[Drowned World Tour 2001]]'' *Released: November 2001 *Studio: Cream Cheese Films, Tadpole Films *Label: Maverick, [[Warner Bros. Records|Warner Bros.]], Warner Reprise Video, Warner Music Vision *Format: VHS, DVD, VCD | *Contains the [[Drowned World Tour]], shot live from [[The Palace of Auburn Hills]] in Michigan, Detroit, August 26, 2001. Contains a photo gallery and on-screen song lyrics.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/work/madonna-drowned-world-tour-perf-255499|title=Madonna: Drowned World Tour > Overview |last=Seibert|first=Perry|date=2008-09-12|work=Allmovie|publisher=Rovi Corporation|accessdate=2009-12-11}} Was certified platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] for shipment of 100,000 units in the United States. |- |2007 |''[[The Confessions Tour]]'' *Released: January 2007 *Studio: [[Semtex Films]] *Label: Warner Bros., Warner Music Vision *Format: CD, DVD | *Contains the [[Confessions Tour]], shot live from London, England, in 2006. Debuted at fifteen on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] on the issue dated February 2, 2007.{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/news/better-late-than-never-jones-debuts-at-no-1003542795.story|title=Better 'Late' Than Never: Jones Debuts At No. 1|last=Cohen|first=Jonathan|date=2007-02-07|work=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|accessdate=2009-12-11}} |- |- |2010 |''[[Sticky & Sweet Tour (album)|Sticky & Sweet Tour]]'' *Released: March 2010 *Studio: Semtex Films *Label: Warner Bros., [[Live Nation]] *Format: CD, DVD, [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]] | *Contains the [[Sticky & Sweet Tour]], shot live from [[River Plate Stadium]], [[Buenos Aires]] in December 2008.{{cite news|url=http://www.madonna.com/news/title/madonnas-sticky--sweet-concert-to-be-released-march-30th-on-dvd-bluray-and-cd|title=Madonnaâs âSticky & Sweetâ Concert To Be Released March 30th On DVD, Blu-Ray And CD|accessdate=2010-01-12|date=2010-01-12|last=Reporter|first=Icon|work=''Icon: Official Madonna website''|publisher=Madonna.com}} Debuted at ten on the ''Billboard'' 200, becoming Madonna's nineteenth top-ten album.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/album/madonna/sticky-sweet-tour/1330476|title=Billboard â Madonna â The Sticky & Sweet Tour|work=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc}} |- |} ===Music video compilations=== {| class="wikitable" !align="center" | Year !align="center" width="350"| Video details ! Notes |- |1984 |''[[Madonna (album)#Promotion|Madonna]]'' *Released: November 1984 *Label: Sire, Warner Music Video *Format: VHS, Laserdisc | *Includes the music videos of "Burning Up", "Lucky Star", "Borderline" and "Like a Virgin". Was the top-selling music video cassette of 1985.{{cite journal|last=Vare|first=Ethlie|date=1985-11-23|title=Music Videocassette Chart Review|journal=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|volume=97|issue=47|pages=14|issn=0006-2510|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=jCQEAAAAMBAJ&dq=madonna+music+video+compilation&source=gbs_navlinks_s}} Was certified two times platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] for shipment of 100,000 units in the United States. |- |1990 |''[[The Immaculate Collection (video)|The Immaculate Collection]]'' *Released: November 1990 *Label: Sire, Warner Bros., Warner Reprise Video, Warner Music Vision *Format: VHS, Laserdisc, DVD | *Promotional music videos from 1983 to 1990. Includes "Lucky Star", "Borderline", "Like a Virgin", "Material Girl", "Papa Don't Preach", "Open Your Heart", "La Isla Bonita", "Like a Prayer", "Express Yourself", "Cherish", "Oh Father", "Vogue" and its live performance from the [[1990 MTV Video Music Awards]].{{harvnb|Taraborrelli|2002|p=303}} Was certified three times platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America for shipment of 150,000 copies. |- |1999 |''[[The Video Collection 93:99]]'' *Released: October 1999 *Label: Warner Bros., Warner Reprise Video, Warner Music Vision *Format: VHS, DVD | *Promotional music videos from 1993 to 1999. Includes "Bad Girl", "Fever", "Rain", "Secret", "Take a Bow", "Bedtime Story", "Human Nature", "Love Don't Live Here Anymore", "Frozen", "Ray of Light", "Drowned World", "Power of Goodbye", "Nothing Really Matters" and "Beautiful Stranger".{{cite journal|date=1999-11-06|title=Top Upcoming DVDs|journal=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|pages=7|issn=0006-2510|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=eggEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA7-IA2&dq=madonna+video+collection+93:99&cd=4#v=onepage&q=madonna%20video%20collection%2093%3A99&f=false}} Was certified platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] for shipment of 50,000 units in the United States. |- |2009 |''[[Celebration: The Video Collection]]'' *Released: September 2009 *Label: Warner Bros. *Format: DVD | *DVD containing forty-seven music videos, released alongside the ''[[Celebration (Madonna album)|Celebration]]'' compilation album.{{cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/news/madonna-s-celebration-hits-collection-to-1003996769.story|title=Madonna's 'Celebration' Hits Collection To Feature Two New Songs|last=Caulfield|first=Keith|date=2009-07-23|work=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|accessdate=2009-12-10}} Was certified platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] for shipment of 50,000 units in the United States. |} ===Box sets=== {| class="wikitable" !align="center" | Year !align="center" width="350"| Video details ! Notes |- |2000 |''The Ultimate Collection'' *Released: September 2000 *Label: Warner Bros., Warner Reprise Video, Warner Music Vision *Format: VHS, DVD | *UK only box set includes the video release of ''[[The Immaculate Collection (video)|The Immaculate Collection]]'' and ''[[The Video Collection 93:99]]''. Released in both VHS and DVD box sets.{{Cite music release notes |Name=The Ultimate Collection|Artist=Madonna|Year=2000|Publisher=[[Warner Music Vision]]|PID= 7599-38519-3}} |- |2000 |''[[The Madonna Collection]]'' *Released: September 2000 *Label: Warner Bros., Warner Reprise Video, Warner Music Vision *Format: VHS | *UK only VHS box set includes ''[[Live â The Virgin Tour]]'', ''The Immaculate Collection'' and ''[[The Girlie Show â Live Down Under]]''.{{Cite music release notes |Name=The Madonna Collection|Artist=Madonna|Year=2000|Publisher=[[Warner Music Vision]]|PID= 7599-38517-3}} |} ===Promotional videos=== {| class="wikitable" !align="center" | Year !align="center" width="350"| Video details ! Notes |- |1987 |''It's That Girl'' *Released: September 1987 *Label: Sire, [[Warner Music Group|WEA Records UK]] *Format: VHS, Cassette | *UK-only 14 track promotional instore compilation "to commemorate the [[Who's That Girl World Tour|1987 World Tour]]", created by WEA Records UK and issued to record shop retailers. Includes the music videos: "Holiday" (1984 ''[[Top of the Pops]]'' performance), "Lucky Star", "Like a Virgin", "Material Girl", "Into the Groove", "Angel", "Dress You Up" (Live), "Borderline", "Live to Tell" (Original version with gun-scene), "Papa Don't Preach", "True Blue" (Remix), "Open Your Heart" (Remix), "La Isla Bonita" (Remix) and "Who's That Girl".{{Cite music release notes |Name=It's That Girl|Artist=Madonna|Year=1987|Publisher=[[Sire Records|Sire]], WEA Records UK|PID= SAM 379}} |- |1990 |''[[Blond_Ambition_World_Tour#She.27s_Breathless_promotion|She's Breathless]]'' *Released: July 1990 *Label: Sire, Warner Bros., WEA Records UK *Format: VHS, Cassette | *UK-only 18 track promotional instore compilation to promote the 1990 [[Blond Ambition World Tour]], created by WEA Records UK and issued to record shop retailers. Includes the music videos: "Like a Virgin", "Material Girl", "Into the Groove", "Angel", "Dress You Up" (Live), "Borderline" (Edit), "Live to Tell" (Edit without gun-scene), "Papa Don't Preach", "True Blue", "Open Your Heart" (Remix), "La Isla Bonita" (Remix), "Who's That Girl", "Causing a Commotion" ([[Ciao, Italia! â Live from Italy|Live from Italy]]), "Like a Prayer", "Express Yourself", "Cherish", "Dear Jessie" and "Vogue". A 20-track cassette version was also issued.{{Cite music release notes |Name=She's Breathless|Artist=Madonna|Year=1990|Publisher=[[Sire Records|Sire]], Warner Bros., WEA Records UK|PID= SAM 684}} |- |1999 |''[[Ray_of_Light#Promotion|Rays of Light]]'' *Released: 1999 *Label: Maverick, Warner Bros., Warner Music UK *Format: VHS | *UK-only promotional instore compilation which includes all the music videos to all five singles from the album ''[[Ray of Light]]''. All five videos were later included on the 1999 compilation ''[[The Video Collection 93:99]]''.{{Cite music release notes |Name=Rays of Light|Artist=Madonna|Year=1999|Publisher=Maverick, Warner Bros., Warner Music UK|PID= PRO-RAY-VHS}} |- |- |2001 |''[[GHV2]]'' *Released: November 2001 *Label: Maverick, Warner Bros., Warner Music UK *Format: VHS | *UK-only promotional instore video including "Music" (Dan-O-Rama Remix) music video to promote ''GHV2''. Artwork also refers to the album being named ''Greatest Hits â The Second Coming'', its original title.{{Cite music release notes |Name=GHV2|Artist=Madonna|Year=2001|Publisher=Maverick, Warner Bros., Warner Music UK|PID= SAM 925}} |- |} ===Documentaries=== {| class="wikitable" !align="center" | Year !align="center" width="350"| Video details ! Notes |- |1991 |''[[Truth or Dare (documentary)|Truth or Dare]]'' (aka ''In Bed with Madonna'') *Released: March 1991 *Studio: Boy Toy, Inc., [[Miramax Films]], [[Dino de Laurentiis]] *Label: [[Artisan Entertainment|LIVE Entertainment]], [[Artisan Entertainment|Artisan]], [[Video Collection International|Video Collection]] *Format: VHS, DVD | *Documentary following the 1990 [[Blond Ambition World Tour]]. Includes live performances of "Express Yourself", "Oh Father", "Like a Virgin", "Live to Tell", "Holiday", "Vogue" and "Keep It Together".{{cite news|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/reviews/movie/5948931/review/5948932/truth_or_dare|title=Truth or Dare: Review|last=Sheward|first=Don|date=2000-12-08|work=Rolling Stone|publisher=Jann Wenner|accessdate=2009-12-11}} |- |2006 |''[[I'm Going to Tell You a Secret#Album release|I'm Going to Tell You a Secret]]'' *Released: June 2006 *Studio: [[Maverick Films]], River Road Entertainment, Lucky Lou Productions *Label: Warner Bros., Warner Music Vision *Format: DVD + CD | *Documentary following the 2004 [[Re-Invention World Tour]]. Also includes a live CD album. Debuted at 33 on the ''Billboard'' 200.{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r834380|pure_url=yes}}|title=allmusic ((( I'm Going to Tell You a Secret > Overview )))|last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas|date=2004-09-04|work=Allmusic|publisher=Rovi Corporation|accessdate=2009-12-11|authorlink=Stephen Thomas Erlewine}} |- |} ==Video singles== {| class="wikitable" !align="center" | Year !align="center" width="350"| Video details ! Notes |- |1990 |"[[Justify My Love#Music video|Justify My Love]]" *Released: December 1990 *Label: Sire, Warner Bros., Warner Reprise Video, Warner Music Vision *Format: VHS Video Single | *Promotional music video of "Justify My Love" and "Vogue" performed live at the [[1990 MTV Video Music Awards]]. It was certified four times platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America for shipment of 200,000 copies of the single. The video has sold 440,000 copies.{{harvnb|Rooksby|2004|p=6}} It is the best-selling music video single of all time.{{cite journal|last=Pietrolungo|first=Silvio|date=1998-07-18|title=Video Singles Look For Higher Retail Profile|journal=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|volume=110|issue=29|pages=83|issn=0006-2510|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=9wkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA83&dq=madonna+justify+my+love+video+single&cd=3#v=onepage&q=madonna%20justify%20my%20love%20video%20single&f=false}} |- |1998 |"[[Ray of Light (song)#Music video|Ray of Light]]" (Special Limited Edition) *Released: June 1998 *Label: Maverick, Warner Bros., Warner Reprise Video, Warner Music Vision *Format: VHS | *Promotional music video for "Ray of Light". It sold 7,381 copies in its first week. |- |2000 |"[[Music (Madonna song)#Music video|Music]]" *Released: September 2000 *Label: Maverick, Warner Bros., Warner Reprise Video, Warner Music Vision *Format: DVD | *Promotional music video for "Music". It was certified gold by the Recording Industry Association of America for shipment of 25,000 copies of the single. |- |2001 |"[[What It Feels Like for a Girl#Music video|What It Feels Like for a Girl]]" *Released: April 2001 *Label: Maverick, Warner Bros., Warner Reprise Video, Warner Music Vision *Format: VHS, DVD | *Promotional music video for "What It Feels Like for a Girl" |} == See also
